# Hogan and Martha A. Runkle Queen House

| locmapin = Iowa#USA
| area = less than one acre
| built = 1856
| builder =
| architect =
| architecture =
| added = September 29, 1987
| mpsub =

The Hogan and Martha A. Runkle Queen House is a historic residence located southeast of Earlham, Iowa, United States.  Hogan Queen settled in Madison County in 1853.  Within two years he had acquired  of land, and his land holdings eventually grew to .  In addition to farming, Queen was a livestock dealer and he operated a stagecoach stop in his home.  The house was also believed to be a stop on the Underground Railroad.
The house is an early example of a vernacular limestone farmhouse. This 2Â½-story asymmetrical massed rectangular structure is composed of ashlar finished cut quarry faced stone and rubble.  The stone may have been quarried on the farm.  The house features cut out bargeboards, a protruding water table and lintel course, and a gable roof.   It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1987.
